marketNews.title: Realization of the 2024 State Budget: Deficit On Target
marketNews.content:
Realization of the 2024 State Budget (APBN): Deficit on Target

Finance Minister Sri Mulyani on Monday (6 January) announced that the 2024 fiscal deficit reached 2.29% of GDP, meeting the original target even though it is larger than the 2023 APBN result of 1.61% of GDP. The result is also lower than the Ministry of Finance's September 2024 outlook, which projected the 2024 deficit would widen to 2.7% of GDP. The better‑than‑outlook performance was supported by easing oil price pressure, commodity price recovery, low and stable inflation, and the recovery of the rupiah against the US dollar.

Although the economy still grew, total tax revenue was the only APBN 2024 account that did not meet its target, mainly due to a contraction in tax receipts in the first half of 2024. This result was pressured by a significant decline in corporate income tax (PPh badan) (‑18% YoY) caused by lower profitability of the coal and palm oil sectors as commodity prices moderated in H1 2024. On the other hand, transactional tax receipts grew solidly, such as PPh 21 (+21% YoY) and VAT/PPN‑BM (PPN/PPnBM) (+8.6% YoY), supported by wage and THR payments.

In the same briefing, Sri Mulyani also said the Ministry of Finance forecasts Indonesia’s 2024 economic growth to be around +5% YoY (vs. 2023: +5.05% YoY), in line with consensus estimates but lower than the government’s target of +5.2% YoY. BPS has not yet released 4Q24 growth data.

For 2025, the government targets a 2.53% of GDP deficit, with government spending (+8.1% YoY) expected to grow faster than state revenue (+5.7% YoY).

Key Takeaway

Although the 2025 deficit is projected to rise this year, it could be higher than the estimate due to the cancellation of the increase in the general sales tax (PPN) for goods and services and the launch of the 2025 stimulus package. However, the risk may ease if those policies generate positive consumer spending impacts, thereby still increasing total tax revenue.

In addition, the implementation of the Coretax system is also expected to boost overall tax receipts. Maintaining the budget deficit at a stable level could help keep the rupiah stable – especially amid global uncertainties such as geopolitics, Fed interest‑rate moves, and the new US administration’s policies.

marketNews.title: Indonesia Becomes Permanent BRICS Member
marketNews.content: Brazil announced on Monday (6 January) that Indonesia will become a permanent member of the BRICS bloc. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Tuesday (7 January) that Indonesia welcomed the announcement, adding that BRICS membership is a strategic way to increase collaboration and partnership with other developing countries. In addition to Indonesia, the current permanent BRICS members are Brazil, Russia, India, China, South Africa, Egypt, Ethiopia, Iran, and the United Arab Emirates. Indonesia’s accession comes amid the election of US President Donald Trump, who said he would impose a 100% tariff on BRICS member countries if the bloc acted to weaken the US dollar.

marketNews.title: Retirement Age Raised to 59 Years Starting 2025
marketNews.content: The government officially set the retirement age for Indonesian workers at 59 years starting in 2025. The provision, regulated in Article 15 of Government Regulation No. 45/2015, applies to workers who wish to draw benefits from the BPJS Ketenagakerjaan pension program. The regulation changes the retirement age from the previous 56 years, which was raised to 57 years in 2019, and will increase by one year every three years until reaching a maximum of 65 years.

marketNews.title: Constitutional Court Declares Article 251 of Commercial Code Conditionally Unconstitutional
marketNews.content: The Constitutional Court on Friday (3 January) ruled that the provision in Article 251 of the Commercial Code is conditionally unconstitutional. The ruling means insurance companies can no longer unilaterally cancel claims. Insurance analyst Wahyudin Rahman said the decision will have a significant impact on the insurance industry, potentially leading to more claim disputes. Meanwhile, Nicolaus Prawiro, Vice President of Insurance Cakrawala Proteksi Indonesia, said the ruling forces insurers to be more careful in business acceptance.

marketNews.title: Daihatsu and Toyota LCGC Prices Rise with Higher VAT and Motor Vehicle Tax Option
marketNews.content: Director of PT Astra Daihatsu Motor, Sri Agung Handayani, said that the selling price of low‑cost green cars (LCGC) from Daihatsu increased in January 2025 due to the rise of the value‑added tax to 12% and the implementation of a motor vehicle tax option. In addition, Marketing Director of PT Toyota Astra Motor, Anton Jimmi Suwandy, said Toyota’s LCGC models also saw price increases for the same reasons.

marketNews.title: Bulog Raises Domestic Rice Procurement Target to 3 Million Tonnes in 2025
marketNews.content: Bulog increased its domestic rice procurement target from 1.27 million tonnes in 2024 to 3 million tonnes in 2025. Coordinating Minister for Food Affairs Zulkifli Hasan said Indonesia will not import rice in 2025, opting to maximise domestic procurement during the March‑May harvest peak. By comparison, Indonesia imported more than 3.7 million tonnes of rice in 2024. Reuters reported that Indonesian rice production is expected to rise from 30.34 million tonnes in 2024 to 32.8 million tonnes in 2025.

marketNews.title: Trade Ministry Sets 2025 Export Target of US$294.45 Billion
marketNews.content: Trade Minister Budi Santoso said the government targets Indonesia’s 2025 export value to grow +7.1% YoY to US$294.45 billion (IDR 4,770 trillion). He also said the ministry has calculated the export target that must be achieved for 2025‑2029 to support the President’s goal of +8% GDP growth by 2029. The ministry targets export values of US$315.31 billion in 2026, US$340.2 billion in 2027, US$370.04 billion in 2028, and US$405.69 billion in 2029.

marketNews.title: Domestic Travel Falls 24.9% YoY During Holiday Season
marketNews.content: The Ministry of Transportation reported that the number of people traveling domestically during the Christmas and New Year period (18 December 2024 – 5 January 2025) was 94.67 million people, a decline of 24.92% YoY. The Ministry’s survey cited weather, lack of permits, insufficient funds, and the proximity of the March 2025 Eid al‑Fitr as reasons for the drop.

marketNews.title: MBDK Excise Implementation Pending Economic Outlook
marketNews.content: The Directorate General of Customs and Excise of the Ministry of Finance said the government will consider the national economic condition in the first half of 2025 before implementing the sweetened‑beverage (MBDK) excise. The government targets MBDK excise revenue of IDR 3.8 trillion in 2025.

marketNews.title: IKN Budget Implementation Reaches 97.3% of 2024 Allocation
marketNews.content: Deputy Finance Minister Suahasil Nazara said the IKN (new capital) budget implementation reached IDR 43.4 trillion, 97.3% of the total 2024 allocation of IDR 44.5 trillion. The result brings the cumulative IKN construction spending for 2022‑2024 to IDR 75.8 trillion. The total IKN cost is estimated at IDR 466 trillion, with only about IDR 89.4 trillion expected from the state budget.

tickerNews.title: BMRI Seeks US$1 Billion Syndicated Loan
tickerNews.content: Bank Mandiri reported that it is seeking a US$1 billion three‑year syndicated loan. Bloomberg named Australia & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd., CIMB Bank Bhd., DBS Bank Ltd., HSBC Holdings plc, Oversea‑Chinese Banking Corp., and United Overseas Bank Ltd. as the arrangers. Bloomberg also said BMRI will pay a margin of 65 basis points over the Secured Overnight Financing Rate. BMRI has not responded to the report.

tickerNews.title: MIDI Reports Strong FY24 Same‑Store Sales Growth and Store Expansion
tickerNews.content: Midi Utama Indonesia reported same‑store sales growth (SSSG) of +9.13% YoY in 4Q24 (vs. 3Q24: +11.07% YoY). The result lifted FY24 SSSG to +9.86% YoY, surpassing the upgraded target of +9% YoY. MIDI also disclosed that it opened 203 new stores in 2024, exceeding the 200‑store target (101.5% of target), bringing the total number of Alfamidi stores to 2,435 at year‑end 2024. For FY25, management targets 200 new Alfamidi stores and mid‑single‑digit SSSG.

tickerNews.title: Hillcon Sells 37 Million HILL Shares at Premium
tickerNews.content: PT Hillcon Equity Management sold 37 million HILL shares at IDR 2,800 per share on 3 January 2025, 19.7% above the closing price of IDR 2,340 per share on the same day. The transaction value was IDR 103.6 billion. After the transaction, Hillcon’s ownership in HILL fell from 63.01% to 61.76%.

tickerNews.title: PGAS Prepares Regasified Gas Supply for 2025 Industrial Demand
tickerNews.content: Corporate Secretary of Perusahaan Gas Negara, Fajriyah Usman said the company is preparing regasified gas as an alternative gas source as industrial demand rises. PGAS estimates that pipe‑gas supply challenges will arise in 2025, making regasified gas likely to increase its share to meet industrial needs. Although regasified gas has a different cost structure than pipeline gas, PGAS said it will continue to provide innovative solutions to keep the economics and competitiveness of customers. The comment followed a statement by the Chairman of the Association of Ceramic Industries, Edy Suyanto, that PGAS is applying a regasified‑gas price of US$16.77 per MMBtu for the period 1 January‑31 March 2025, a 21.08% premium over the surcharge for users exceeding the industrial gas allocation.

tickerNews.title: TCPI Targets 5‑15% Cargo Volume Growth and IDR 700 Billion 2025 Capex
tickerNews.content: Transcoal Pacific’s corporate secretary, Anton Ramada, said the company is targeting a cargo volume increase of about +5‑15% YoY in 2025, with a revenue growth target of +15% YoY and net profit of +10‑15% YoY. To achieve the targets, TCPI will allocate IDR 700 billion in capex for 2025 (vs. IDR 450 billion in 2024) to add 12 new vessels – 2 pusher barges, 4 tugboats and 6 barges – and to fund ship docking.

tickerNews.title: PGEO Plans US$300 Million 2025 Capex for Geothermal Expansion
tickerNews.content: Pertamina Geothermal Energy’s corporate communication manager, Muhammad Taufik, said the company is allocating US$300 million in 2025 capex (vs. US$247 million in 2024) to develop strategic geothermal projects and reach the company’s installed capacity target of 1 GW. The business reported that PGEO’s installed capacity currently stands at 672 MW.

tickerNews.title: MMIX Forms Joint Venture for Tissue and Non‑Woven Paper
tickerNews.content: Multi Medika Internasional and Fujian Nicepaper Hygiene Products Co. announced the formation of a joint venture called PT Multi Nice Paper Indonesia (MNPI). The joint venture’s paid‑in capital is IDR 310 million, with MMIX holding a 15% stake. The JV will operate in the tissue and non‑woven paper sector. The announcement came a few days after MMIX announced a memorandum of understanding on a diaper‑factory project in Tangerang, Banten with Fujian Nicepaper Hygiene Products Co.

tickerNews.title: ALII Shares Sold for IDR 120.3 Billion to Borneo Logistics Services
tickerNews.content: Ancara Logistics Indonesia, a shareholder of Ancara Logistics Indonesia, sold approximately IDR 1.7 billion of ALII shares to Borneo Logistics Services Pte. Ltd. at IDR 69 per share on 27 December 2024. The transaction value was IDR 120.3 billion. PT Borneo Logistik Indonesia explained the sale was to settle debt. After the transaction, Borneo Logistics’ ownership in ALII fell from 11.02% to zero, while Borneo Logistics Services’ stake rose to 11.02%.
